newsitem.title: INDIA: Hoechst seeks to exploit India auto boom.
newsitem.headline: Hoechst seeks to exploit India auto boom.

text.p: German chemicals group Hoechst AG is looking at ways to profit from the emerging automobile boom in India, senior officials said on Friday.
"We have several things in the mind," Utz-Helmuth Felcht, member of the board, told reporters.

Bernhard Hofmann, managing director of Hoechst South Asia Investment Ltd, a wholly-owned subsidiary, said group firm Herberts GmbH was close to signining a joint venture with Indian paint maker Jenson & Nicholson to manufacture automotive repair paints.

Hofmann said Trevira India Ltd, a 50-50 joint venture with India's Reliance Industries Ltd to manufacture polyester tyrecord, was expected to begin production at Hazira on the western coast in the next 18 months.
"We have environment-friendly water-based paint technology which is widely used in car manufacture," Felcht said.
"We want to convince new car manufacturing units to be built in India to invest in water-based coating lines," he said.
Ford Motor Co, Hyundai Motor Co, Toyota Motor, Honda Motor Co Ltd, and Volkswagen are some global majors planning to make cars in India.

Hofmann said his group was also seeking to increase its presence in plastics as many plastic automobile components are still imported. The group may establish a compounding facility to supply Indian plastic processors in the near future, he added.
